reviews.review_text: It's very polished, the music is incredible, and it looks lovely. The item descriptions are full of snide and sometimes sinister remarks. The general atmosphere of the game is a blend of frenetic happiness with dark undertones, and it conveys that really well.  Otherwise... I mean I get that it's satirising consumer culture, mobile games with micro-transactions, and entertainment addiction... But in the end all you're doing is burning things, collecting coins, and burning more things. You're doing the things you're supposed to be laughing at.  As for the story being told, it never really resolves into anything that makes much sense; instead it's happy to drop hints here and there and pull at your heartstrings without substance.  What little gameplay is there is pretty refined - the burning effects and physics are fun to toy with. I think 'toy' is more fitting for this than 'game.'  Overall, I still recommend it because it's so well put together. And really, I want that soundtrack.

If Little Inferno was content to be merely a game about sticking a variety of different objects into a fireplace and watching them burn until reduced to ash, it would still be recommendable, as it's full of fun and inventive items to play with. However, the game goes beyond it's surface premise, offering up a critique of its very own genre and a potentially thought provoking story set in an often unsettling and sometimes outright scary world.  As the world gets colder and colder, The Tomorrow Corporation releases the Little Inferno Entertainment Fireplace, which you are a brand new owner of. In order to combat the frigid temperatures outside, you'll spend your days throwing everything from credit cards to televisions to robots (and much, much weirder things) into your fireplace. As you burn, unlocking new items from the 7 different catalogs, you'll interact with others through letters where most of the story is told.  While there are a large amount of items to unlock, and subsequently turn to ash, as well as “Combo” puzzles to solve, most of the focus of Little Inferno is on the setting and story. A story that, whether by authorial intent or not, is often vague and never very upfront with its intentions. This implicit style of storytelling allows the player to glean however much or little from the game as they want. Is the game really just about burning cool stuff? Or is it using an environmental message as a vessel to tell a deeper metaphorical tale? It's really up to you and how far you want dig into the game.  If that idea turns you off, and $10 seems too steep a price to satiate your inner pyromaniac, this may not be the game for you. For everyone else, whether for its impressive fire effects, its haunting soundtrack, or its intriguing story, Little Inferno is a game likely to stick with you well after you finish it.

As user Puggsoy put, 'Little Inferno is not a game of skill. It's a game of discovery.' That is exactly what the game is. I've read that some people were disappointed, claiming that the game felt like it was missing something or lacking, but it's all in the eye of the beholder. I was perfectly pleased and fell in love with it. There's not a lot of challenge to it, if any, but there is a lot of beauty and discovery and fun for the curious who like to experiment. This is not a game for the people who crave constant action or stimulation. If anything, Little Inferno will soothe and calm you. There's something very relaxing about watching the objects burn, and the atmosphere has a very ambient feel despite wondering about the sinister intentions behind your Little Inferno Fireplace that was given to you by a big company, Tomorrow Corporation, that you know very little about. But the premise is that the world around you is freezing, and you have to keep burning things to stay warm and farther more, although it's unspoken, most likely to stay alive.  This game is often described as a 'Fireplace simulator,' but there's a little more to it than that. It has a plot with a few surprises with a twist that left me surprised and emotional. On top of that, watching things burn never grow tiring. In fact, they often burn with pizzazz. There are a lot of unexpected outcomes, from sounds, to special effects, to beautifully colored flames. You'll be excited to burn the next thing to see how it reacts.

They force you to think, not just about what items to burn together to unlock combos, but about why you are doing what you are doing. This game is witty, engaging, satirical, and haunting in a way that creeps up on you. Absolutely brilliant.

Little Inferno is an odd quasi-puzzle game with a similar style and consumerism narrative as World of Goo, 2D Boy's previous acclaimed release. The player is simply tasked with ordering items from a catalog and then burning them in the Little Inferno fireplace. The challenge comes from unlocking more advanced item catalogs, which require a certain amount of burn combinations to access, but you're really here to just be a virtual pyromaniac. Item design is excellent -- I love the screams from the school bus -- and the game's gradually unfolding story (told via snailmail letters) keeps you enthralled to the end. Little Inferno lacks the replayability of World of Goo, but it's an excellent experience on its own.

Although I haven't finished this game yet, I realize from browsing the forums how controversial this game is, so I feel compelled to add my two cents.  If you're looking at this game because you want stunning gameplay, turn back now. If you recognize the simple gameplay and want it because 'LOL BURNING STUFF 10/10' then buy it, but realize you're missing the best part of the game.   The main complaint I see about this game is that it's 'simply burning stuff with no goal, and it gets repetitive.' This is halfway true. Yes, it gets repetitive. But the gameplay is not the main point of the game. Much like To The Moon, you don't play for the gameplay but rather for the story or ambience. If this doesn't suit you, then it's simply not the game for you.   That leads to the other complaint: 'There is no story' or 'The message is dumb and forced.' To this, I have to outright disagree. If you haven't heard this yet, the game is satire for time management games. (Crazy, right? It's not just burning stuff!) To those who think this message is just tacked on at the end (and maybe it is, I haven't actually seen the ending yet), it's actually carefully seeded throughout the game. Take Sugar Plumps for example. She's your slightly annoying neighbor who speaks like a ten year old who's learned how to text and illustrates the type of people who play these games. She bugs you about how much she loves the 'game' but wants some extra (useless) content for it. (Plus, she bugs you to send her items, which kind of reminds me of the stupid Candy Crush feature.) Then there's Miss Nancy, who tells you you're 'doing so well' when you really haven't done anything.   Besides the hidden themes, the developers masterfully created an atmosphere that should grab you right from the title screen. The art style, soundtrack, and allusions to a decaying world outside work together to create a unique feeling of interest. Also, this game was co-developed by Kyle Gabler, maker of World of Goo (if you couldn't tell by the art style). Much like World of Goo, he succeeded in creating that maelstrom of emotions- you're amused by the burning, but perplexed about why you're doing it, intrigued by the underlying story, apalled by the screaming toys, and sometimes outright horrified by *certain* events (no spoilers). Seriously, just watch the trailer. Think about how the music contrasts with the images to make you wonder how you really should be feeling. How many times have you seen that in a game?  But to be honest, the game does get annoying in its criticism-by-imitation. The game makes you wait ridiculously long times to receive your items, or use in-game items to quicken this process (sound familiar?). While this certainly adds to its idea, it makes the game annoying to play through. And honestly, it's way overpriced at normal price, though luckily this is Steam and we get great deals all the time. So if you're thinking about buying it, it really comes down to your personal preferences. If you appreciate games that are unique and sacrifice gameplay for experience, this is definitely worth trying.  My that's a big wall of text, but I had too much to say. For the record, I played this for just over an hour and got 4 catalogues in before getting tired of the issue detailed below.  Overall this game just doesn't hold up. While playing it I considered that as a 'free to play' it might be acceptable... but the more I played the more I realized that even then it's a game that's more irritating than fun. I play AdVenture Capitalist and Clicker Heroes and Swarm Warp, and those are all terrific examples of free to play time eating games. The thing about each of them is, I can get involved, or I can walk away and let them run and stuff keeps happening in the background. But this game... this game unfortunately both requires your attention for things to progress, but also has what I feel is a completely unnecessary imposed time limit on its item orders. I'm not sure why that felt like a necessary addition in a game this simple and straightforward.   To begin with the positive, I like the design, it's very nice, and there's an interesting little story development with the neighbor - and this is a case where the game introduces a time-eating element that actually works - the letters reveal very little at a time, but it's not irritating, because you're still getting something out of it (letters, items, mild amusement at the letters - if you've ever watched Tiny Toons, don't be surprised if you find yourself reading her letters in Elmyra Duff's voice). There are also some fun animations with the burnings - I especially liked the marshmallows and the opera singer. And the idea of combinations is fun. Unfortunately all of that was just 'mildly entertaining' and therefore not enough to overcome the rising irritation of waiting to continue playing.  So, the negative: picture sitting at your computer for an hour with several episodes of 'okay, now stare at the screen for 2 minutes', that's what this game is. As someone else pointed out in a positive review, it's not enough time to do something else, but it's enough time to be annoying as you stare at the screen waiting for anywhere between a few seconds and 2 minutes to pass for *each order* so you can burn something else - it gets more annoying the more combos you're looking for, especially with a limit of 4-ish items at once, which can be *slowly* expanded by spending money for more slots. But you can only buy one.... slot....at...a...time. Everything about that just seems like 'we don't feel like our game's long enough to ask for money for it' but honestly the time wasting elements are exactly what make me not recommend this game. Little Inferno is a great game, but it's important to know what it is. On the simplest level, it's simply burning things in a fireplace. What impresses me so much with this is that the physics of burning stuff is done quite well, and there's something satisfying just watching stuff burn (as there should be) and that alone was fun to play with for a while.  The next level is the combo system, whereby you get some extra perks by burning certain objects together. For the most part, these can be figured out with a bit of thinking, although there's a few of them that I think are not 'good' solutions. Or at least, I think there's more sensible solutions to it. There's 99 combos, and I'd say about 2/3rds can be gotten relatively easily, but the last few can be really tricky.  On the final level, there's a sort of plot-based undercurrent in here that I think is really interesting initially, but ultimately unsatisfying. It is sorta similar to how World of Goo had a similar plot that is introduced very subtly. I really wish that the plot had been a bit more fleshed out, I get hints of a larger message it was meant to lead to, but it feels indecisive about it.  Overall, the game's a fun 4-5 hours and I think there's a good sense of humour to it. There's some forced waiting in the game that I think could've been reduced so that late game was less tedious at points (particularly when trying to figure out combos). That said, unlike World of Goo, there really isn't replay value, unless you enjoy watching the fire. There's nothing to go back and try to earn once you have figured out all the combos so I do think it's important to know that buying this game is buying a 4-5 hour experience and not much more than that.

Little Inferno features trivial gameplay to gradually tell a story. Its not exciting but it has a charm for those who appreciate it. I also got it in a humbe bundle so I didnt invest the 10 bucks on it, but I would say that if you can get it on a good sale it will make a good pass-time. The simple experimenting of combinations is enjoyable enough and the passive story-telling all the while makes the story more... sincere? It just makes the perspective feel more relatable, and there is a satisfaction in discovering the resolution.  If youve played World of Goo, Id say this game is a little less gameplay and a little more story than Goo, which isnt entirely a bad thing. Id never spend 10 bucks on it (I tend to be fairly frugal), but like I said, if youve got a sale (or humble bundle) its pleasant.   All in all, if you don't think youll like something with such unengaging gameplay, youre probably right. If you do, you will. And Im not saying youll only like it if you know youll like it. If youre not sure if it would be a hit or a miss for you, theres a fair chance on the hit.
